In Galliformes, the sex of an individual is determined by the presence of a W chromosome. The Galliform sex-determination system is the opposite of the system found in mammals, in which individuals with two X chromosomes are female and those with one X and one Y chromosome are male. In the Galliform system, the W chromosome initiates the development of testes, and the female genotype is ZW. In chickens, the Z and W chromosomes are largely homologous, and strains that are homozygous for either the Z or W chromosome are fertile. However, in hybrids between these two strains, the heterozygous ZW individual is female and infertile.

Document-1: BACKGROUND: The C677T polymorphism of the methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) gene has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease in several populations. It is uncertain whether this association is mediated by an increase in plasma homocysteine concentration. METHODS: We utilized a Mendelian randomization approach to examine the causal relationship between the C677T polymorphism, plasma homocysteine concentration, and the risk of myocardial infarction (MI; n=630), ischemic stroke (IS; n=433), and peripheral arterial disease (PAD; n=166) inukuaket008 Chinese adults. RESULTS: The TT genotype was associated with a 0.39 mmol/L (95% confidence interval [CI], 0.16-0.62 mmol/L) higher plasma homocysteine concentration and a 1.57-fold increased risk of MI (95% CI, 1.15-2.15), a 1.71-fold increased risk of IS (95% CI, 1.03-2.84), and a 2.09-fold increased risk of PAD (95% CI, 1.10-3.99) compared with the CC/CT genotype. After adjustment for plasma homocysteine concentration, the association between the C677T polymorphism and the risk of MI, IS, and PAD was attenuated and became nonsignificant. CONCLUSIONS: Our data suggest that the increased risk of MI, IS, and PAD observed in carriers of the C677T polymorphism is attributable to the increase in plasma homocysteine concentration.

INTERPRETATION In four European countries, reductions in smoking prevalence were associated with reductions in smoking-related mortality during a period when smoking-related diseases were the leading cause of avoidable death in middle-aged women and men.

OBJECTIVE To examine whether pioglitazone use for diabetes is associated with risk of bladder and 10 additional cancers. DESIGN, SETTING, AND PARTICIPANTS Cohort and nested case-control analyses among persons with diabetes. A bladder cancer cohort followed 193,099 persons aged 40 years or older in 1997-2002 until December 2012; 464 case patients and 464 matched controls were surveyed about additional confounders. A cohort analysis of 10 additional cancers included 236,507 persons aged 40 years or older in 1997-2005 and followed until June 2012. Cohorts were from Kaiser Permanente Northern California. Crude incidences of bladder cancer in pioglitazone users and nonusers were 89.8 and 75.9 per 100,000 person-years, respectively.
